Rental gear on Bali, had a fluctuating pressure gauge that I should have mentioned on my first dive. On second dive, we stayed down deep for a bit looking for a pygmy seahorse -- which we eventually found, but by the time we were coming back up slowly, and I was at 50 bar I found it incredibly hard to breath. I would get a little bit at first, then the gauge would drop to zero and it was like trying to drink out of a closed straw. One of the guys we dove with the day before reported a similar issue. Couple that with a longer than normal safety stop (+8 minutes ASC warning since we stayed down too long on our second dive after a deep first dive) and I started freaking out a bit and shared air with our guide. Luckily, I didn't just pop up but remained somewhat calm and shared air. Scary experience.
Lesson learned: Always speak up about any issues with your gear -- especially rental gear, immediately.

WRITING.TITLE: Having some Mild Barotrauma after a week of diving!
WRITING.TEXT: Back from a week of diving in Roatan (amazing BTW) and I'm experiencing what I've self-diagnosed as a case of MEBT (middle-ear barotrauma) after looking around online. I got back late Sunday but the first time I really noticed the symptoms, ringing in the ear, a feeling like I'm underwater, some slight discomfort, began on Monday morning. Since then it's persisted mainly localized to my right ear. From what I've read online, and from what DAN emailed me back after inquiring advice from a medic, it seems like the only thing to do it wait ... and see and hope it isn't a perforated eardrum of an inner ear barotrauma or something worse. I'm taking sudafed but I'm a little worried about how long it's going to take since I don't have insurance and don't want to go to a DR if the problem is just going to clear up... Anyone with any experience, let me know how it goes for you.

I get that people on both sides are getting fucked by others (LE, exit-scammers, etc.) but there is a departure from what you're calling baseline ethical behavior when a vendor cancels orders knowing that those who placed their faith in him to deliver a product for the money they put up will now possibly get neither.

The thing about LOST was that, we as viewers know we're watching a show with actors and we suspend our disbelief if the fiction is good enough, and especially for the first season, maybe two or two and a half seasons, the show was really great fiction, but like the X-Files before it, LOST collapsed under the weight of its own distended mythology. And what happened was the characters, no matter how fully realized or articulated or conflicted or REAL they seemed, were flailing about in a context which had no internal consistency or plan, which made their actions, and ultimately themselves lose any meaning for the audience.
Of course, it's the characters stupid, to paraphrase Stephen King, but it's also the context of those characters, and while mystery is interesting, what LOST exposed is that there needs to be an endgame planned from the start
